It is undoubtedly one of the most important unaesthetic sequelae of periodontal disease","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5isb1","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"tosr","text":"Cunliffe et al. evaluated in 2009 the perception of 80 randomly selected patients in terms of the number of visible black triangles and their severity. They concluded that the presence of black triangles was the third most unpleasant aesthetic problem after caries and dark crown margins","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"apaph","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3s0tg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5r6ks","text":"The technique we are going to describe is known as \"injection molding\". Based on the use of a patented matrix system (Bioclear. Washington. USA) by Dr. David Clark, which is combined with a refined technique that simultaneously uses flowable composite and conventional heated composite (nanofiller/microhybrid). The clinical procedure consists of 10 steps that must be performed in order.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"91sb4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4prv2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"afrlp","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bq0v6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"Novak M. J. Albather H. M. \u0026 Close, J. M. ","can_edit":true,"date":1224028800,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1902/jop.2008.080066","guid":"DE3E4BF01C9A11EE8C9261C9ECFC3640","id":2361,"journal":"J  Periodontol","protocol_id":null,"title":"Redefining the biologic width in severe, generalized, chronic periodontitis: implications for therapy"}},"1":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"Cunliffe J. Pretty  I.","can_edit":true,"date":1232668800,"doi":"PMID: 20158060","guid":"B22D35C01C9B11EE8C9261C9ECFC3640","id":2362,"journal":"Eur. J. Prosthodont. Restor. Dent. ","protocol_id":null,"title":"Patient's ranking of interdental “black triangles” against other common aesthetic problems. "}},"2":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Clark D","can_edit":true,"date":1225497600,"doi":"https://doi.org/","guid":"8B350F101C9111EE87EEEBC3E0952B5C","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"\"Restoratively driven papilla regeneration: correcting the dreaded 'black triangle'\"."}},"3":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"align":"","authors":"Clark D","can_edit":true,"date":1328054400,"doi":"https://doi.org/","guid":"9FE2CA601C9111EE87EEEBC3E0952B5C","id":0,"journal":"","protocol_id":0,"title":"\"The mother of all black triangles\" case."}}}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"efeg9","text":"CONTEXT\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aqj57","text":"The treatment of open gingival embrasures area, also known as black triangles, has always been a frequent reason for consultation in daily practice. It is undoubtedly one of the most important unaesthetic sequelae of periodontal disease [1]. Cunliffe et al. evaluated in 2009 the perception of 80 randomly selected patients in terms of the number of visible black triangles and their severity. They concluded that the presence of black triangles was the third most unpleasant aesthetic problem after caries and dark crown margins [2].","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"60qa0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5t78d","text":"The etiology of black triangles is multifactorial, depending on the interproximal space between the teeth, the distance between the position of the contact point and the bony ridge, the gingival biotype, the age of the patient, the severity of the periodontal disease, the presence of divergent roots and, finally, the morphology of the tooth and whether it is more or less predisposing (triangular), or an inadequate contour of a pros-thetic crown and/or restoration [3].","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b5vg6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"l5dl","text":"One of the most frequent moments for the appearance of black triangles is after orthodontic treatment [4]. Kurth and Kokich published a study in 2001 with 337 patients from their private practice to assess the prevalence of black triangles between the upper central incisors after orthodontic treatment. The study showed that the prevalence of in-complete papillae between the upper incisors was approximately one third of the population. Another classic study by Burke et al. in 1994 estimated that 15% of adolescent patients undergoing orthodontic treatment for crowding of the upper incisors could expect the presence of black triangles after treatment [5].","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5u3ts","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6aj3c","text":"Surgical techniques such as platelet rich fibrin (PRF) or connective tissue graft (CTG) in papilla reconstruction to treat these sequelae have a greater or lesser degree of recurrence over time [6]. The limited blood supply to the papilla is a problem that determines the reaction of this tissue to any trauma or intervention, however minor. A review published in 2020 by Zhang et al. concludes that minimally invasive procedures, such as hyaluronic acid or low power laser photobiomodulation, still require further observation to confirm their long term efficacy [7].","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"qh60","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"av69o","text":"The protocol we are going to describe is known as \"injection molding\". Based on the use of a patented matrix system (Bioclear. Washington. USA) by Dr. David Clark [8, 9], which is combined with a refined technique that simultaneously uses flowable composite and heated conventional composite (nanofiller/microhybrid). The clinical procedure consists of 10 steps that must be performed in order.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
keywords: injection molding,cosmetic restoration,microhybrid,black triangles,heated composite,natural emergence profile

references.title: "The mother of all black triangles" case.
Redefining the biologic width in severe, generalized, chronic periodontitis: implications for therapy
references.authors: Novak M. J. Albather H. M. & Close, J. M.

references.title: Patient's ranking of interdental “black triangles” against other common aesthetic problems.
"Restoratively driven papilla regeneration: correcting the dreaded 'black triangle'".

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working.

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4csi2","text":"Pre-treatment analysis of the gingival embrasure area and selection of the corresponding bioclear black triangle (BT) matrix.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"75sc9","text":"Smoothing and relief of the interdental contact points.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5p183","text":"This second step consists of checking the interproximal contact points to eliminate possible irregular areas such as sharp edges and/or overflow of fillings that could tear the rubber dam that we use to perform the technique by means of absolute isolation. It also facilitates the removal of bacterial plaque and/or calculus present on the interdental surface. It is also an important step to facilitate the correct and complete seating of the matrices, since in situations where there is a strong contact point, it can be difficult to insert them due to their thickness. It is important to perform this procedure gently to relieve the contact point, but without losing it, as this could also compromise the subsequent stabilization of the matrices. Polishing strips can be used for this purpose (Figure 2a). If a higher degree of relief is required, the manual sanding set is a good alternative (Figure 2b). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":908,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"F520CC601BFC11EEB478EBEA7A3D077B","height":184,"id":387505,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"5iipf\",\"text\":\"Figure 2. Contact point relief with Sof-Lex strips (a) (3M ESPE. Minnesota. USA) or “tru-contact” manual sanding (b) (Bioclear).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":52,\"length\":1},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":114,\"length\":1}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4pvbn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4ptbn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4pubn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4psbn3x7.webp","width":524}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"2t4mb","text":"Fitting the rubber dam.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"esubn","text":"This step is performed with a BT calibration probe (Bioclear). This is a plastic in-strument designed to calibrate the open gingival embrasure area and coded with four colors (pink, yellow, blue, and green). Each color is associated with a BT bioclear matrix, making selection easy and intuitive. To do this, the probe is inserted into the black triangle from vestibular to palatal/lingual until it stops (Figure 1a). Then, it is observed from incisal (Figure 1b) by selecting the matrix that corresponds to the color that we observe in the probe once it has been inserted into the black triangle.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"biqm6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65pg2","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"CEE0EDA01BFC11EEB478EBEA7A3D077B","height":149,"id":387509,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"2se5e\",\"text\":\"Figure 1. Analysis of the open gingival embrasure area, frontal (a), and occlusal view with the \\\"BT\\\" calibration probe (b) (Bioclear).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":65,\"length\":1},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":120,\"length\":1}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4pzbn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4pxbn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4pybn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4pwbn3x7.webp","width":513}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"96jj3","text":"These anatomical matrices are specifically designed for the closure of black triangles with composite. They have some distinguishing features that facilitate this procedure in an efficient and conservative manner with the remaining tooth structure. These matrices are rigid and withstand the force required to insert the filling material without overflowing and are highly resistant to deformation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ep9mc","text":"At the same time, they are flexible enough to adapt to the anatomy of the tooth, providing an optimal seal at the marginal level. These are self-stabilizing matrices so that, with the interdental contact point present, there is no need for any accessory elements (wedges, rings) to fix them and hold them in position. In addition, there are different emergence profiles that allow them to cope with all clinical situations that arise during daily practice. Their composition is mylar type polyester, which provides a satin finish to the restorative material in the cervical interdental area (a critical area due to the difficulty of access). Due to its transparency, excellent polymerization of the composite is possible.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9unpj","text":"There are two available sizes of anatomical matrices.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"igd9","text":"Small: for mandibular central and lateral incisors, including small maxillary lateral incisors.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4qhnr","text":"Large: for maxillary central and lateral incisors, including maxillary and mandibular canines.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"113bh","text":"The technique of black triangles closure by this procedure is performed with absolute isolation by means of a rubber dam since it improves our working conditions by keeping a wide, clean, and dry surgical field, which is essential when using adhesive techniques. Of all the advantages offered by the rubber dam in restorative dentistry, the most important in this context is the retraction of the soft tissues (tongue, lips, cheek and gum) because it facilitates access and improves the field of vision to an already sensitive area (Figure 3a). The presence of the rubber dam also helps to stabilize the matrix apically, due to the pressure it exerts on the matrix and therefore on the neck of the tooth. A medium-thickness latex dam is usually recommended, as it provides optimal tissue retraction and is resistant to tearing during passage through interdental contact points. The anchorage clamp of the rubber dam is always placed one or two teeth posterior to the most distal tooth on which we are working to not interfere with the restorative procedure (Figure 3b).  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":1070,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"2FAA74801BFD11EEB478EBEA7A3D077B","height":152,"id":387513,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"b0h4v\",\"text\":\"Figure 3. Absolute isolation with Nic tone rubber dam (MDC Dental. Jalisco. Mexico), frontal (a) and occlusal view (b).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":93,\"length\":3},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":115,\"length\":3}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4p5bn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4p3bn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4p4bn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4p2bn3x7.webp","width":512}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"6crcl","text":"Bacterial plaque removal and substrate conditioning.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8us24","text":"This step is crucial to ensure the adhesive procedures, it is essential that the bacterial plaque present is completely removed. To facilitate its visualization and subsequent removal, we brush the surface of the tooth (focusing on gingival embrasure area) with a plaque-revealing solution for   (Figure 4a). Then rinse thoroughly with water, observing the bacterial plaque present on the surface of the tooth (Figure 4b). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":294,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":422,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":20,"guid":"034232E0196711EEBF19E15283586103","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"5BAFAE601BFD11EEB478EBEA7A3D077B","height":205,"id":387517,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"4kms4\",\"text\":\"Figure 4. Revealing bacterial plaque (Biocleardual color disclosing. Bioclear) (a,b). \",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":79,\"length\":5}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4p9bn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4p7bn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4p8bn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4p6bn3x7.webp","width":506}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8a6kb","text":"Elimination of bacterial plaque, as well as any extrinsic stains present on the surface of the tooth, is performed using ultrasonic instruments (Figure 4c) and bicarbonate spray (Figure 4d).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"du7gn","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"90F253201BFD11EEB478EBEA7A3D077B","height":140,"id":387521,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"3f3fl\",\"text\":\"Figure 4. Removal of bacterial plaque with ultrasound (c) (universal tip no. 1. Acteon Satelec.  Aqui-taine. France) and/or bicarbonate spray (d) (Air-n-go easy. Acteon Satelec).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":10},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":54,\"length\":3},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":142,\"length\":4}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qdbn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qbbn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qcbn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qabn3x7.webp","width":516}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"7evi2","text":"Placement of BT bioclear matrices.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2v56m","text":"Conditioning of the substrate allows to improve adhesion to the enamel including the exposed root surfaces. It will also allow stability of the restoration margins by reducing the incidence of staining in the tooth-composite transition. This conditioning is performed by sandblasting with aluminum oxide, with a particle size of 29 microns, dry (Figure 4e) or combined with water (Figure 4f).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7tmnr","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"B25BF1B01BFD11EEB478EBEA7A3D077B","height":149,"id":387525,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"907kv\",\"text\":\"Figure 4. Conditioning of the substrate with dry aluminum oxide (e) (Dento-prep. Ronvig. Copenhagen. Denmark) or mixed with water (f) (Aquacare. Velopex. London. UK).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":10},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":64,\"length\":4},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":131,\"length\":1}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qhbn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qfbn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qgbn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qebn3x7.webp","width":514}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4n1qe","text":"Once the substrate has been conditioned and the matrices have been selected, we proceed to place them in the black triangle to be reconstructed. It is recommended to insert the first matrix obliquely with the index finger and thumb, exerting apical pressure until it stops (Figure 5 a, b). After checking that it is correctly and completely seated, we repeat the procedure with the adjacent matrix (Figure 5c). Occasionally, due to the thickness of the matrices and the resistance of the interdental contact point, it may be necessary to use a composite spatula to facilitate the insertion of the second matrix (Figure 5d). Once the first matrix is in place, we insert the spatula through the black triangle and make a rotating movement, resting on the matrix. This way, we facilitate the opening of the contact point and the insertion of the second matrix. Their rigidity will prevent them from deforming during this procedure. Finally, we make sure that both matrices are at the same height so that they are well seated (Figure 5e).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"34man","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":1,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"DF6F40301BFD11EEB478EBEA7A3D077B","height":575,"id":387529,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"dvk9b\",\"text\":\"Figure 5. Placement of the matrices to treat the central black triangle (a,b,c,d). Detail of the placement of the small BT matrices in position (e) (Bioclear).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":73,\"length\":7},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":145,\"length\":1}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qmbn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qjbn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qkbn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qibn3x7.webp","width":508}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"2jkla","text":"Acid etching.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"aii19","text":"After correct placement of the matrices, the enamel and exposed root surfaces are etched with orthophosphoric acid. It is preferable to etch with the matrices in place as they act as a formwork favoring the penetration of the acid to the most apical part of the gingival embrasure area (Figure 6 a, b). After  , rinse thoroughly for the same time and dry gently.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":309,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ec9pf","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":30,"guid":"3D264C30196711EEBF19E15283586103","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"137D83A01BFE11EEB478EBEA7A3D077B","height":152,"id":387533,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"chcit\",\"text\":\"Figure 6. Simultaneous conditioning of both teeth with orthophosphoric acid (a,b) (37%. Proclinic. Barcelona. Spain).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":77,\"length\":3}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qrbn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qpbn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qqbn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qnbn3x7.webp","width":510}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"6l63m","text":"Application of adhesive agent and polymerization.\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"a7kep","text":"There are many systems to choose from in this category. The first option is the classic 4th generation system that consists of conditioning, primer, and bond separately. Alternatively, the 5th generation system consists of a conditioning, like the previous system, but primer and bond are one solution. Lastly are universal adhesives, also known as self-etch systems, but it is highly recommended to always condition before using adhesives with orthophosphoric acid to optimize adhesion to the enamel [9]. The latter are preferred because of their lower technical sensitivity during the procedure. Brushing of the bonding agent should be performed in an active way, trying to access the entire tooth surface to be restored both vestibular (Figure 7a) and palatal/lingual (Figure 6b). Finally, polymerization is performed for   on each surface.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":825,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"rdus","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"duration":20,"guid":"481D4DF0196711EEBF19E15283586103","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"42D3BD401BFE11EEB478EBEA7A3D077B","height":150,"id":387537,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"dto02\",\"text\":\"Figure 7. Vestibular (7a) and lingual (7b) bonding agent application.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":22,\"length\":2},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":39,\"length\":2}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qvbn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qtbn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qubn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qsbn3x7.webp","width":512}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d0pvo","text":"Injection of the flowable composite and composite paste onto the matrix.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7ua5d","text":"The injection molding procedure involves the sequential injection of a balanced mixture of preheated, nanofilled, flowable and paste composites into the anatomical matrix, which surrounds the tooth and acts as a reservoir containing the material.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"57rc3","text":"First, the flowable composite preheated to 68° in a dry oven (bioclear HeatSync heater. Bioclear.)  is applied in vestibular, from the base of the black triangle to the incisal without polymerization (Figure 8a). The procedure is repeated on the palatal/lingual side of the matrix, also with flowable composite (Figure 8b). Immediately thereafter, the paste composite, also preheated [10], is placed vestibular in the flowable composite pool until the latter overflows the incisal edge (Figure 8 c, d). The aim is to push the flowable composite into the narrower areas by filling the space within the matrix. This requires excess material as it will reduce the possibility of bubbles and/or pores in those areas that are difficult to access. This procedure is performed at the same time on the teeth to be restored, on both matrices facing each other. A video to explain this step better:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ba1v8","text":"https://www.dropbox.com/preview/PROTOCOLS.IO/inyecci%C3%B3n.m4v","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":63}],"data":{}},{"key":"c6793","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9a16u","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"158CFDAE1BFB11EEBF230A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.dropbox.com/preview/PROTOCOLS.IO/inyecci%C3%B3n.m4v"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"47A37FB01BFC11EEB478EBEA7A3D077B","height":313,"id":387541,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"b64r3\",\"text\":\"Figure 8. Application of composite, in the top photos the detail of the tip of the syringe of the flowable composite can be seen (Filtek Supreme XTE A1 flow. 3M ESPE.) placed at the base of the vestibular and lingual black triangle (8a,8b). In the bottom photos a detail of the opening of a matrix with the tip of the compul (8c) (Filtek Supreme XTE. A1B. 3M ESPE.) and in the last picture the composite mix applied and the excess overflowing incisal (8d).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":233,\"length\":5},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":325,\"length\":3},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":452,\"length\":2}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qzbn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qxbn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qybn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4qwbn3x7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4v9fu","text":"Simultaneous polymerization of the composite mixture and matrices removal.\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eh56i","text":"Polymerization is performed at the end of the injection molding procedure once both consistencies of restorative material have been placed in the anatomical matrix. Polymerization is done 20s per side, vestibular (Figure 9a) and palatal/lingual (Figure 9b). After simultaneous polymerization of both composite consistencies, the matrices are removed with the help of mosquito forceps (Figure 9 c, d). Black triangle restorations made with the injection molding procedure are based on excess restorative material (e, f, g, h), it is necessary to check the perfect three-dimensional filling of the black triangle before starting de finishing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3h8nk","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"795E9B3017A511EE898DA9882CABD016","height":803,"id":387545,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"3fise\",\"text\":\"Figure 9. Polymerization of the composite, 20s for each surface and removal of matrices (a, b). Detail of matrix removal with mosquito forceps, previously it is necessary to open it a little to eliminate the vacuum effect (c). The restorations just after removing the matrices are a perfect model of them (d). Vestibular (e, f) and palatal (g, h) details of the restorations before finishing.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":89,\"length\":4},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":223,\"length\":1},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":306,\"length\":1},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":322,\"length\":4},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":341,\"length\":4}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4q5bn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4q3bn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4q4bn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4q2bn3x7.webp","width":550}}}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"o51l","text":"Polishing of excess composite and finishing the restoration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"85tbr","text":"When performing this step, we must consider that at no time should we touch the emergence profile created with the matrices, since the composite in contact with the matrix is polished with a satin aspect due to the material these matrices are made of.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"83e4p","text":"Finishing the restoration is done in three stages. First, the thick excess composite is removed from easily accessible areas such as the vestibular and palatal/lingual surfaces. This is done with burs and rotatory instruments at high speed and water irrigation (Figure 10a). The second phase involves polishing and recontouring the restoration. As we approach the tooth surface, we use tungsten carbide burs (Figure 10b) and polishing discs of decreasing particle size to blur the tooth-restoration transition (Figure 10 c, d). Finally, we proceed to fine polishing and shining using diamond rubber discs (Figure 10 e, f, g, h) and contra angle handpiece at low-speed alternating irrigation with water. In the end, the result is an anatomical restoration with a closed gingival embrasure from vestibular (Figure 10i) to palatal (Figure 10j) aspect.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eh7gf","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"9E1CE1401BFE11EEB478EBEA7A3D077B","height":749,"id":387549,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"aq7ou\",\"text\":\"Figure 10 Different stages of finishing with diamond (a) 862-012 (MDT. Haifa. Israel) and tungsten carbide (b) H379AGK burs (Komet. Lemgo. Germany). This was followed by a disc of descending par-ticle size (c,d) (Sof-lex. 3M ESPE.) and finally polished with a disc, but this time made of rubber (e,f, g, h), preferably diamond (EVE diacomp plus twist. Keltern. Germany). Final result from vestibular and palatal aspect (i, j).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":9},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":54,\"length\":1},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":108,\"length\":1},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":207,\"length\":3},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":296,\"length\":9},{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":420,\"length\":4}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4q9bn3x7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4q7bn3x7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4q8bn3x7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/m4q6bn3x7.webp","width":535}}}}
